course.title: Intro Geology How Earth Works
course.catalog-description: A fascinating tour of our active planet. Explore earth materials (rocks and minerals), the continents' motions and related origins of earthquakes, volcanoes, mountain building, oceans, landscapes, natural energy and economic resources, global warming and other topics. Students are encouraged but not required to enroll concurrently in 105L. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area III: Science (NMCCN 1114).

course.title: Introductory Macroeconomics
course.catalog-description: Economics on a national scale: determination of national income, employment level, inflation and impact of policies affecting money supply, interest rates and government programs. Current macroeconomic issues and problems. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area IV: Social/Behavioral Sciences (NMCCN 2113). (Prerequisite for most upper-division courses).

course.title: Introductory Microeconomics
course.catalog-description: Exploration of individual consumer behavior, production decisions by the firm and supply and demand relationships in the marketplace. Examination of the international dimension of production and consumption choices. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area IV: Social/Behavioral Sciences (NMCCN 2123). (Prerequisite for most upper division courses.)

course.title: Money and Banking
course.catalog-description: Principles of money, credit and banking; organization and operation of the banking system; and the relationship between money, banking and the level of economic activity. Prerequisite: 303.

course.title: Intro Envir Sci Tech
course.catalog-description: An introduction to the socially and politically constructed values directing Americans' attitudes toward nature, science and technology and to the impacts of those attitudes on built and natural environments regionally, nationally and globally.

section.text: Online course, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Intro Race Class Ethn
course.catalog-description: An interdisciplinary introduction to the issues of race, class and ethnicity in American life and society. {Fall, Spring}

course.title: Intro to SW Studies
course.catalog-description: Provides both an introduction to the complex history and culture of the Southwestern United States and a demonstration of the possibilities of the interdisciplinary study of regional American culture. It is multicultural in its content as it is multidisciplinary in its methodology.

section.text: Online course, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Topic in Gender Studies
course.catalog-description: Varying subjects deriving from the contemporary cultural studies focus on matters of gender. Topics include: feminist theory; gender and nature; the factor of gender in disciplinary and interdisciplinary studies.

course.title: Blacks in the US West
course.catalog-description: (Also offered as AFST 307) A survey of the lives of Blacks in the American West (1528-1918).

course.title: T: Women Studies
course.catalog-description: Can be repeated for credit three times by students earning a major or minor in Women Studies. {Fall, Spring}

course.title: American Politics
course.catalog-description: Survey of American politics, including political behavior of the American electorate, the theory of democracy, the structure and function of American political institutions, and contemporary issues. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area IV: Social/Behavioral Sciences (NMCCN 1123). {Fall, Spring}

course.title: Comparative Politics
course.catalog-description: Designed to give students the ability to understand and evaluate political regimes by focusing on the political history, socioeconomic structure and contemporary political institutions and behavior. Includes consideration of European and developing systems. {Fall, Spring}

course.title: Political Ideas
course.catalog-description: Introduces many of the enduring political issues in descriptive, analytical and normative terms. Will include discussion of both classical and contemporary political ideas and ideologies. {Fall, Spring}

section.text: Internet course please visit http://online.unm.edu,Rescheduled from CRN 21714 POLS 260 001.

course.title: Public Policy & Administration
course.catalog-description: Introduces public policy and bureaucracy, including decision-making and implementation. {Fall, Spring}

course.title: Intro To Political Analysis
course.catalog-description: Discovery of causal patterns in political behavior, evaluation of the effectiveness of political reforms and campaign techniques, analysis of the logic of scientific research and related topics. No knowledge of statistics, computers or research methods assumed. {Fall, Spring}

course.title: Intro to the Study of Language
course.catalog-description: (Also offered as ANTH 110) Broad overview of the nature of language: language structure, biology of language, language learning, language and thought, bilingualism, social and regional variation and educational implications. Intended to fulfill breadth requirements in any college. 101 and ANTH 110 may not both be counted for credit.

course.title: Western Civilization to 1648
course.catalog-description: Ancient times to 1648. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area V: Humanities and Fine Arts (NMCCN 1053). {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Western Civilization post 1648
course.catalog-description: 1648 to present. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area V: Humanities and Fine Arts (NMCCN 1063). {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: US History to 1877
course.catalog-description: Survey of the economic, political, intellectual and social development of the United States, including the place of the U.S. in world affairs from 1607 to 1877. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area V: Humanities and Fine Arts (NMCCN 1113). {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: US History since 1877
course.catalog-description: Survey of the economic, political, intellectual and social development of the United States, including the place of the U.S. in world affairs from 1877 to the present. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area V: Humanities and Fine Arts (NMCCN 1123). {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: History of New Mexico
course.catalog-description: Introduction to New Mexico history from earliest human settlement to the present day.

course.title: Hispanic Frontiers
course.catalog-description: History of colonial encounters, Indian-European exchanges and conflicts, environmental transformations and changing identities at the northern frontiers of New Spain and Mexico. From the time of Columbus to 1848.

course.title: Elementary Spanish I
course.catalog-description: Beginning Spanish for students with no previous exposure to Spanish. Development of all four language skills, with emphasis on listening and speaking.

course.title: Elementary Spanish II
course.catalog-description: Beginning Spanish for students who have completed 101 or equivalent. Continued development of four skills with emphasis on listening and speaking.

course.title: T: Hisp Culture & Language
course.catalog-description: Taught in Spanish (required for major study).Emphasis on oral and written expression based on a theme or language related topics (literature, culture, civilization, translation, commercial, etc.) Consult current major requirements for number of times course may be repeated for credit.

course.title: Dev Spanish Writing Skills
course.catalog-description: Taught in Spanish (required for major study). Emphasis on developing Spanish written expression.

course.title: Intro Hispanic Literature
course.catalog-description: Examination of selected Spanish and Spanish-American literary texts representing old and new literary currents. Special attention will be given to stylistics and the analysis of style and literary language. Prerequisite: 301 and Pre- or corequisite: 302.

course.title: Advanced Grammar
course.catalog-description: Required for Spanish majors. Taught in Spanish. Analysis of morphological and syntactic structure. Pre- or corequisites: 302.

course.title: Spanish American Short Story
course.catalog-description: Spanish American short story from 19th century to contemporary period. Intensive development and discussion of theoretical bibliography. Prerequisite: 302 and 307.

course.title: ST: Physics & Astronomy
course.catalog-description: Special topics beyond our standard curriculum, usually involving new areas. The actual topic will vary and will be defined by the instructor. Restriction: permission of instructor.

section.section-title: ST: Med Acc Lasr & Pla Med Acc
Adv T: Med Acc Lsr Pla Med Acc

course.title: General Psychology
course.catalog-description: Overview of the major content areas in psychology. Topics to be covered include learning, cognition, perception, motivation, biological systems, social and abnormal psychology, development, personality and approaches to psychotherapy. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area IV: Social/Behavioral Sciences. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Statistical Principles
course.catalog-description: Presentation of the basic principles of the description and interpretation of data. Provides an acquaintance with statistical principles appropriate to a liberal arts education, as well as a basis for further work in data analysis. Students planning graduate study in any field are advised to take 300 and 302 as well. Prerequisite: 105.

section.text: Online course, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Developmental Psychology
course.catalog-description: Overview of the physical, perceptual, motor, cognitive, emotional and social development of children from infancy through adolescence. Prerequisite: 105. {Fall, Spring}

section.text: Online course visit: http://online.unm.edu/schedule,Rescheduled from CRN 18091 PSY 220.040.

course.title: Psychology of Human Sexuality
course.catalog-description: (Also offered as WMST 231) Exploration of the physiological, cultural, social and individual factors that influence sexual behavior, sex roles and sex identity. Prerequisite: 105.

course.title: Brain & Behavior
course.catalog-description: A general survey of the biological foundations of behavior. Emphasis is on the central nervous system. Prerequisite: 105 or BIOL 110 or BIOL 123. {Fall, Spring}

course.title: Cognitive Psychology
course.catalog-description: Study of the cognitive processes involved in the encoding, storage, retrieval and use of knowledge including attention, memory, comprehension, categorization, reasoning, problem solving and language. Prerequisite: 105. {Fall, Spring}

section.text: Online course visit: http://online.unm.edu/schedule,Rescheduled from CRN 23037 PSY 265.040.

course.title: Social Psychology
course.catalog-description: Study of social influence: perception of oneself and others, attitudes, conformity, attraction, altruism, aggression, and groups. Prerequisite: 105. {Fall, Spring}

course.title: Health Psychology
course.catalog-description: This course introduces Health Psychology. The course will cover the role of stress in illness, coping with chronic illness, stress, and pain, and the role of health behavior in health and disease. Prerequisite: 105.

course.title: Psychology Research Techniques
course.catalog-description: Application of the concepts covered in 200. Includes discussion of basic principles of research design and scientific methodology as applied to psychology. Prerequisite: 200.

course.title: Infant Development
course.catalog-description: An advanced course that presents theory and research on the physical, cognitive, social, emotional, perceptual and motor development in the first two years of life. Prerequisite: 220.

course.title: Adolescent Psychology
course.catalog-description: Empirical study of adolescent development from different theoretical perspectives. Organization of individual social patterns through cultural and historical transitions and interplay between risk and protective factors in healthy development as well as deviant behaviors. Prerequisite: 200 and 220.

course.title: Psychology of Personality
course.catalog-description: Survey of theory, research and applications of both classical and contemporary approaches to the study of personality. Prerequisite: 200 and 220.

course.title: Abnormal Behavior
course.catalog-description: Review of the historical, scientific and ethical issues in the field of psychopathology. Categorization of deviant behavior, theories of abnormal behavior, systems of therapy and relevant research are covered. Prerequisite: 105.

course.title: Human Learning & Memory
course.catalog-description: How humans acquire and use knowledge. Theoretical and applied issues discussed around the topics of memory structures, attention, forgetting, mnemonics, imagery and individual differences in memory. Prerequisite: 260 or 265.

course.title: Psychology of Perception
course.catalog-description: Study of the methods organisms use to gain information about objects. The sensory processes are discussed as a basis for description of more complex perceptual phenomena. Prerequisite: 260 or 265.

course.title: History of Psychology
course.catalog-description: An introduction to the major developments and individuals in the history of psychology. Prerequisite: any 300-level psychology course.

course.title: Advanced Developmental Psych
course.catalog-description: Investigation of the theoretical bases and critical issues in the area of developmental psychology. Prerequisite: 220.

course.title: Special Topics
course.catalog-description: Study of any psychological topic not otherwise included in the curriculum upon expression of mutual interest by students and faculty. May be repeated for credit. {Offered upon demand}

course.title: Blacks-The US West
course.catalog-description: (Also offered as AMST 351) A survey of the lives of Blacks in the American West (1528-1918).

course.title: Web Design
course.catalog-description: Introduction to writing and designing electronic publications using personal computers and online publishing software. Emphasizes use of graphics and text to communicate with users of the Internet. Competency with personal computers required.

course.title: Theories of Communication
course.catalog-description: Study of the nature of communication theories and theory development, theories of meaning, information processing and influence with applications to selected communication contexts. Prerequisite: 101.

course.title: Nonverbal Communication
course.catalog-description: Theory, analysis and practice of a variety of nonverbal messages, including body movement and appearance, vocal cues and environmental cues.

course.title: Professional Communication
course.catalog-description: Focuses on the written and presentation skills needed to succeed in a professional environment. Lessons emphasize writing reports and proposals, acquiring social information, social interaction skills, the influence of audience on message design and business etiquette.

course.title: Intro Strategic Communication
course.catalog-description: A writing-intensive course with emphasis on history, practice, ethics, professional opportunities and challenges of the field. Strong emphasis on understanding contemporary global strategic communication perspectives and diversity issues.

course.title: Sr Sem Perspectives on Comm
course.catalog-description: In this capstone course, seniors assess the theories, concepts and skills learned throughout their communication major and apply them to real-world situations as well as to the fulfillment of professional, personal and social goals. Prerequisites: 300 and 301 and (332 or 333).

course.title: Health Communication
course.catalog-description: Concepts and strategies for preventive health communication in such contexts as provider-patient interaction, health campaigns, social marketing, health images in the mass media and communication in health care organizations.

course.title: Greek Mythology
course.catalog-description: Introduction to mythology; primary readings in stories about the gods and heroes, usually including Homer, Hesiod, Homeric Hymns and Tragedies. All texts will be in English.

course.title: Elementary French I
course.catalog-description: Conducted in French. {Fall, Spring}

course.title: Intermediate Algebra
course.catalog-description: Preparation for MATH 121, 129 and STAT 145. Covers linear equations and inequalities, polynomials, factoring, exponents, radicals, fractional expressions and equations, quadratic equations, perimeters, areas of simple geometric shapes, AND logarithms. Emphasis on problem solving skills. Acceptable as credit toward graduation, but not acceptable to satisfy UNM core or group requirements. The grading scale for this class is A+ to B-, CR/NC. Prerequisite: ACT=>19 or SAT=>450 or IS-M 100 or Compass Pre-Algebra >56 or Algebra >33 or MATH 100. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: College Algebra
course.catalog-description: Preparation for MATH 150 and 180. The study of equations, functions and graphs, especially linear and quadratic functions. Introduction to polynomial, rational, exponential and logarithmic functions. Applications involving simple geometric objects. Emphasizes algebraic problem solving skills. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area II: Mathematics (NMCCN 1113). Prerequisite: ACT=>22 or SAT=>510 or (MATH 118 and MATH 119) or (MATH 101 and MATH 102 and MATH 103) or MATH 120 or Compass Algebra >54 or College Algebra >33. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Trigonometry
course.catalog-description: Definition of the trigonometric functions, radian and degree measure, graphs, basic trigonometric identities, inverse trigonometric functions, complex numbers, polar coordinates and graphs, vectors in 2 dimensions. May be taken concurrently with MATH 150. Prerequisite: ACT=>25 or SAT=>570 or MATH 121 or Compass College Algebra >54. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Survey of Math
course.catalog-description: An introduction to some of the great ideas of mathematics, including logic, systems of numbers, sequences and series, geometry and probability. Emphasizes general problem-solving skills. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area II: Mathematics. Prerequisite: ACT=>22 or SAT=>510 or (MATH 101 and MATH 102) or (MATH 118 and MATH 119) or MATH 120 or 121 or 123 or 150 or 162 or 163 or 180 or 181 or 264. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Pre-Calculus Math
course.catalog-description: In-depth study of polynomial, rational, exponential and logarithmic functions and their graphs. Includes the fundamental theorem of algebra, systems of equations, conic sections, parametric equations and applications in geometry. Exploration of the graphing calculator. May be taken concurrently with MATH 123. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area II: Mathematics. Prerequisite: ACT=>25 or SAT=>570 or MATH 121 or Compass College Algebra >54.

course.title: Intro To Statistics
course.catalog-description: Techniques for the visual presentation of numerical data, descriptive statistics, introduction to probability and basic probability models used in statistics, introduction to sampling and statistical inference, illustrated by examples from a variety of fields. Prerequisite: ACT = >22 or SAT = >510 or (MATH 118 and MATH 119) or (MATH 101 and MATH 102) or MATH 120 or 121 or 123 or 150 or 162 or 163 or 180 or 181 or 264. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: General Chemistry II
course.catalog-description: Continuation of CHEM 121. Prerequisite: ACT=>25 or SAT=>570 or MATH 121 or MATH 123 or MATH 150 or MATH 162 or MATH 163 or MATH 180 or MATH 181 or MATH 264 and (121 and 123L) or 131L. Pre- or corequisite: 124L. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area III: Science (NMCCN 1224).

course.title: General Chemistry I Lab
course.catalog-description: Introduction to basic chemical laboratory principles and techniques. Prerequisite: ACT Math=>25 or SAT Math=>570 or MATH 121 or MATH 123 or MATH 150 or MATH 162 or MATH 163 or MATH 180 or MATH 181 or MATH 264. Pre- or corequisite: 121. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Topics
course.catalog-description: Titles will vary. Offered on a CR/NC basis only.

section.text: Online course, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu
Online course, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Organic Chemistry
course.catalog-description: Chemistry of the compounds of carbon. Prerequisite: (122 and 124L) or 132L. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Organic Chemistry
course.catalog-description: Continuation of **301. Prerequisite: **301. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Intro To Philosophy
course.catalog-description: Philosophical issues and methodology illustrated through selected problems concerning values, knowledge, reality; and in social, political and religious philosophy. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area V: Humanities and Fine Arts (NMCCN 1113).

course.title: Reasoning & Critical Thinking
course.catalog-description: The purpose of this course is to help students learn how to analyze, critique and construct arguments in context, in other words, how to read and write argumentative essays. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area V: Humanities and Fine Arts.

course.title: Eastern Religions
course.catalog-description: A study of major Asian traditions, such as Taoism, Hinduism and Buddhism. {Fall}

course.title: Western Religions
course.catalog-description: A study of major Western traditions, such as Christianity, Islam and Judaism. {Spring}

course.title: Religion and Literature
course.catalog-description: An introduction exploring relationships between the literary and religious traditions. {Fall}

course.title: Intro to Comm Disorders
course.catalog-description: (Also offered as SPCD 302.) The nature of speech, language and hearing disorders in children and adults; overview of speech and hearing anatomy and physiology; multicultural issues; emphasizes the impact of communicative disorders on individuals and families.

course.title: T:Speech Language Pathology
course.catalog-description: Restriction: enrolled in M.S. S. P.L. P degree program, permission of instructor. {Offered upon demand}

course.title: Accelerated Composition
course.catalog-description: Covers Composition I and II in one semester, focusing on analyzing rhetorical situations and responding with appropriate genres and technologies. Credit not allowed for both ENGL 110 and ENGL 112 or for both ENGL 110 and 113. Meets New Mexico Lower-Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area I: Communications (NMCCN 1113). (EPW) Prerequisite: ISE 100 or ENGL 100 or ACT English => 19 or SAT Verbal => 450 or Compass English >74.

course.title: Composition III
course.catalog-description: Focuses on academic writing, research, and argumentation using appropriate genres and technologies. Meets New Mexico Lower-Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area I: Communications (NMCCN 1123). (EPW) Prerequisite: 110 or 112 or 113 or ACT English 26-28 or SAT Verbal 610-140.

course.title: Tech & Professional Writing
course.catalog-description: Practice in writing and editing of workplace documents, including correspondence, reports and proposals. Prerequisite: 110 or 112 or 113 with a B or better, or 120 with a C or better, or ACT=>26 or SAT=>610.

course.title: Expository Writing
course.catalog-description: An intermediate course with emphasis on rhetorical types, structure and style. Prerequisite: 110 or 112 or 113 with a B or better, or 120 with a C or better, or ACT=>26 or SAT=>610.

course.title: Traditional Grammar
course.catalog-description: A study of the basic analysis of English sentences offered by traditional grammar. Presents terminology and methods for identifying parts of speech, functional units of sentences and basic sentence patterns.

course.title: Survey of Earlier English Lit
course.catalog-description: From Old English to 1798. A study of the principal literary and intellectual movements and selected writers and literary works from Beowulf through Johnson.

section.section-title: Survey of Earlier Engl Lit - C

course.title: Survey of Later English Lit
course.catalog-description: From 1798 to present. Study of principal literary and intellectual movements and selected writers and literary works.

section.section-title: Survey of Later Engl Lit - C

course.title: Earlier American Literature
course.catalog-description: A general survey of American Literature to the mid-19th century.

course.title: Later American Literature
course.catalog-description: A general survey of American Literature from the mid-19th century to the present.

course.title: T: Film and Literature
course.catalog-description: Examination of formal, thematic, and/or historical relationships between literary and cinematic forms, including study of adaptations and/or interrelations between film and literature as a means of cultural expressions.

course.title: History English Lang
course.catalog-description: A historical survey of the etymology, morphology, phonetics and semantics of English, as well as the relation between the English language and cultural change.

course.title: Introduction to Sociology
course.catalog-description: Basic concepts, topics and theories of contemporary sociology. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area IV: Social/Behavioral Sciences (NMCCN 1113). Prerequisite for more advanced courses in sociology. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Social Problems
course.catalog-description: Description and analysis of major social problems facing American society. Foci may include: poverty, homelessness, alcohol and drug problems, race and ethnic relations, aging and mental illness. Prerequisite: 101. {Fall, Spring}

course.title: Causes of Crime & Delinquency
course.catalog-description: A survey of criminological theories exploring why some people are more likely to engage in crime than others and why crime rates vary over time and space and across social groups. Attendant policy issues will also be discussed. Prerequisite: 205 or 211 or 213. {Fall, Spring}

course.title: Sociology of Medical Practice
course.catalog-description: An introduction to the delivery of health care in the U.S. and selected other countries is pursued with an emphasis on the interaction of patients, professionals and health care institutions. {Offered upon demand}

course.title: The Urban Community
course.catalog-description: The forms and development of urban community; demographic, spatial, functional and temporal patterns; metropolitan development and city-hinterland relations. Prerequisite: 101. {Offered upon demand}

course.title: Sociology of Religion
course.catalog-description: (Also offered as RELG 422) Study of belief, commitment, and practice within religious and spiritual traditons and institutions, with a focus on contemporary United States, Latin America, and the Middle East. Prerequisite: 101 or RELG 107 or RELG 263 or RELG 264. {Spring}

department.name: Phys Perform Dev Phy Perf Dev

course.title: Mtr Lrng & Perform
course.catalog-description: Psychological and neurophysiological factors related to the development of motor skills, emphasis on the teacher s role in facilitating learning.

course.title: Professional Orientation
course.catalog-description: Contemporary issues, trends, and ethical considerations in counseling are reviewed and critiqued. Provides an overview of the helping profession, history of the profession, professional roles, organizations, ethical and professional preparation standards, credentialing, and public policy issues. Restriction: admitted to graduate Counselor Education Program.

course.title: Mental Health Counseling
course.catalog-description: An introduction and orientation to the community model. Roles, responsibilities and functions of the community mental health counselor are examined. Knowledge and strategies designed to create systemic changes in clients social environment are presented. Prerequisite: 510 and 517 and 518 and 584. Restriction: admitted to graduate Counselor Education program.

course.title: Family Counseling
course.catalog-description: (Also offered as FS 560.) An introduction to history and practice of counseling with families. A number of leading experts in the field will be studied with respect to their theoretical approach to the subject as well as their techniques. Prerequisite: 510 and 517 and 518 and 584. Restriction: admitted to graduate Counselor Education program.

course.title: Sexuality in Counseling
course.catalog-description: Broadly based examination of psychological, biological and social aspects of sexuality with emphasis on the professional s own values, attitudes and knowledge in working with clients with sexual concerns and problems. Prerequisite: 510 and 517 and 518 and 584. Restriction: admitted to graduate Counselor Education program.

course.title: Research Ch Grth Dev & Lrng
course.catalog-description: This advanced course in child growth, development, and learning builds upon the foundational material covered in the basic course in child growth, development, and learning. An integration of major theories of child development is provided. Prerequisite: 101. Restriction: admitted to the ECME program.

course.title: Human Growth and Development
course.catalog-description: Principles of human growth and development across the life span and implications for education.

course.title: Learning and the Classroom
course.catalog-description: The basic principles of learning, particularly cognition, motivation and assessment, and their application to classroom situations.

course.title: Teaching of Reading
course.catalog-description: Study of reading process for emergent and intermediate readers focusing on: cueing systems, assessment, family and community contexts, language, culture and instruction in individual and small group settings. Lab includes supervised tutoring and discussion group.

course.title: Teaching Reading El Sch
course.catalog-description: Establishing a theoretical framework for exploring various approaches to reading/language development, instruction and evaluation in multicultural classroom settings. Three lectures, 1 hr. lab.

course.title: Techng Read Writ Content Field
course.catalog-description: Course explores issues of literacy development(i.e. reading, writing, listening and speaking) across core content areas of school curriculum. Required in secondary teacher education for all content specialization areas. Restriction: permission of the department.

section.text: Online course, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Research Applications Educ
course.catalog-description: An exploration of the forms of research in teaching and learning. Students have opportunties to identify types of research and determine the significance of the conclusions of research.

course.title: Reading Program in Elem School
course.catalog-description: Prerequisite: 330L.

course.title: Mntoring Educ for Prof Growth
course.catalog-description: This course is designed for active mentor teachers. Participants are reflective practitioners sharing experiences, issues, and suggestions with other mentor teachers.

section.text: Online course visit: http://online.unm.edu/schedule,Rescheduled from CRN 23216 EDUC 563.001.

course.title: Seminar
course.catalog-description: For students in the Department of Teacher Education, this course synthesizes course work which has made up a master's degree program. Enhance and develop competence in professional communication, written and oral.

course.title: Topics in Education
course.catalog-description: May be repeated for credit, no limit.

section.text: Special registration call 277-1154 or email extncred@unm.edu

course.title: Ed Leadership in a Dem Society
course.catalog-description: Designed to help organizational leaders understand how schools have both limited and expanded educational opportunity and what leaders can do to organize educational institutions for democratic life.

course.title: Conflict Resolution
course.catalog-description: This course addresses current theories, strategies and practices in conflict resolution for educational and organizational leaders. Topics such as bullying, peer mediation programs, and restorative justice are covered.

course.title: Tech Integra Effect Instruct
course.catalog-description: Students explore constructivist learning theory as it applies to educational technology as a tool in the learning environment and examine the impact of technology in relation to the changing role of the teacher.

section.text: Online course, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Intl Lit for Young People
course.catalog-description: Seminar surveys international literature for children and young adults, and explores its use in classrooms to build intercultural understanding and global awareness. Texts are critically examined in light of sociopolitical, cultural, and translational issues. Prerequisite: 443 or 544 or EMLS 451 or EMLS 551.

section.text: Online course, for information visit: http://onlline.unm.edu

course.title: Teach Read in Content Flds
course.catalog-description: Course explores issues of literacy development (i.e., reading, writing, listening and speaking) across core content areas of the school curriculum. Required in secondary teacher education for all content specialization areas.

course.catalog-description: May be repeated for credit, no limit.

course.title: Intro To Com Dis
course.catalog-description: (Also offered as SHS 302.) The nature of speech, language and hearing disorders in children and adults; overview of speech and hearing anatomy and physiology; multicultural issues; emphasizes the impact of communicative disorders on individuals and families. Restriction: permission of instructor.

section.text: Online course visit http://online.unm.edu/schedule,Rescheduled from CRN 24055 SPCD 302.002.

course.title: Energy Environment & Society
course.catalog-description: A look at the social, ethical, and environmental impacts of energy use both now and through history. A survey of renewable energy and conservation and their impact on environmental and social systems.

course.title: Dynamics
course.catalog-description: Principles of dynamics. Kinematics and kinetics of particles, systems of particles and rigid bodies. Prerequisite: CE 202 and MATH 264.

section.text: ITV course, for information visit http://itv.unm.edu

course.title: Mechanical Eng Laboratory
course.catalog-description: Measurement techniques and instrumentation for experiments in mechanical engineering, report writing, basic concepts of probability and statistics, discrete and continuous probability distributions, test statistics, classical and robust test of significance, measurement and uncertainty, design of experiments, regression analysis, applications in analysis of engineering experiments. Prerequisite: MATH 264 and PHYC 161. Pre- or corequisite: ECE 203L and MATH **316 . Restriction: ME major.

section.text: ITV course, for information visit http://itv.unm.edu

course.title: Heat Transfer
course.catalog-description: Principles and engineering applications of heat transfer by conduction, convection and radiation. Laboratory experiments and demonstrations of fundamental heat transfer concepts. Prerequisite: 301 and **317L and MATH **316.

section.text: ITV course, for information visit http://itv.unm.edu

course.title: Special Topics Fall
course.catalog-description: Formal course work on special topics of current interest. May be repeated for credit, no limit. Restriction: ME major, senior standing.

section.section-title: ST: Mltbdy Dyn Usng ADAMS View

course.title: Programming Fundamentals
course.catalog-description: Fundamental programming concepts, including consideration of abstract machine models with emphasis on the memory hierachy, basic programming constructs, functions, parameter passing, pointers and arrays, file I/O, bit-level operations and interfacing to external devices.

course.title: Circuit Analysis I
course.catalog-description: Basic elements and sources. Energy and power. Ohm's law and Kirchhoff's laws. Resistive networks, node and loop analysis. Network theorems. First-order and second-order circuits. Sinusoidal sources and complex representations: impendance, phasors, complex power. Three-phase circuits. Prerequisite: 131 and MATH 163. Pre- or corequisite: MATH **316 and PHYC 161.

course.title: Music Appreciation
course.catalog-description: Designed to expand the student's ability to listen actively to Western classical art music; a survey of the various genres, including chamber music, symphonic and vocal repertoire. Includes live guest performances. Attendance at several on-campus concerts required. No musical background necessary. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area V: Humanities and Fine Arts (NMCCN 1113). {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Popular World Music
course.catalog-description: Popular music styles from around the world, such as Reggae, Ska, Samba, Salsa, Flamenco, and Afropop, and artists such as Bob Marley, Ladysmith Black Mambazo, Tito Puente. No musical background necessary. (NM) {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Rock Music Appreciation
course.catalog-description: An introduction to the fundamentals of music and the development of listening skills through the examination of rock music, including its history, styles and significance in the realm of popular music. No musical background necessary. Meets New Mexico Lower-Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area V: Humanities and Fine Arts (NMCCN 1113). {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Jazz History
course.catalog-description: A study of the evolution of jazz in the United States from its beginnings to the present. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area V: Humanities and Fine Arts. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Beatles' Musical Revolution
course.catalog-description: Examines the development of the historical and musical artistry of the Beatles presented within the framework of aesthetic and social/cultural movement 1957-1970 and their individual contributions.

course.title: Film Music History
course.catalog-description: A survey of film music history, technology and technique from the silent film era to the present. No musical experience necessary. (NM) {Summer, Spring]

course.title: Introduction To Art
course.catalog-description: A beginning course in the fundamental concepts of the visual arts; the language of form and the media of artistic expression. Readings and slide lectures supplemented by museum exhibition attendance. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area V: Humanities and Fine Arts (NMCCN 1013). {Fall, Spring}

section.text: Online course, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Interdisciplinary Topics
course.catalog-description: In this studio course, students collaborate on creative problems and projects that combine various art forms.

course.title: Arts Management Internship
course.catalog-description: The arts management internship is required for the minor in Arts Management for both undergraduate and graduate students. Students are required to complete concurrent online training and 150 internship hours onsite under a mentor's supervision. Prerequisite: 250. Restriction: permission of department.

section.text: Online course, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Fine Art as Global Perspective
course.catalog-description: This course introduces interdisciplinary perspectives on fine art fields such as visual arts, theater, architecture, dance and music. Its goal is to encourage understanding of the role of art in society and culture. Restiction: admitted to Honors College.

course.title: Info Mgmt for Professionals
course.catalog-description: Students will create a database of the major information resources within a specific discipline. They will also learn research strategies, and economic and ethical issues surrounding information policy.

course.title: Principles of Adult Learning
course.catalog-description: Explores the world of the adult learner from historic, social, political and pragmatic perspectives. Issues of life stages, culture, teaching theory and andragogical practice are considered as they relate to the practice of adult learning.

course.title: Tech Change & Society
course.catalog-description: Focus on industry as humanity s systematic effort to provide the necessities and conveniences of life. In addition to developing a historical perspective, students will study in depth a variety of industrial organizations that provide goods and services to meet the needs and desires of society.

section.text: Online course visit http://online.unm.edu/schedule,Rescheduled from CRN 23201 OILS 481.001.

course.title: Environmental Information Mgmt
course.catalog-description: An introductory hands-on course on environmental information management and the data life cycle for the environmental sciences. With emphasis on data acquisition technologies, metadata, QA/QC procedures, data preservation, database management and web portal development. Corequisite: 521 and 522.

section.text: Special registration call 277-1154 or email indstudy@unm.edu

course.title: Envir Data Analysis & Visual
course.catalog-description: A hands-on course in Environmental data analysis and visualization, with an emphasis on data exploration, tool assessment, and creation of effective visual representations of analytical results. Corequisite: 520 and 522.

section.text: Special registration call 277-1154 or email indstudy@unm.edu

course.title: Spatial Data Mgmt in Envir Sci
course.catalog-description: Environmental data is generated and visualized by a variety of tools. This hands-on course focuses on how GeoSpatial data generated by GIS systems is effectively managed, analyzed and preserved in the Environmental Sciences. Corequisite: 520 and 521.

section.text: Special registration call 277-1604 or email indstudy@unm.edu

course.title: Topics
course.catalog-description: Used to test new courses. May be repeated for credit, no limit.

course.title: Intro Clin Immunolgy
course.catalog-description: An introduction to the principles of human immune system function with emphasis on developing a general, basic background for those who have no previous experience in immunology or clinical medicine. Prerequisite: BIOL 201L or BIOL 123 and 124L. {Summer}

course.title: Clinical Serology
course.catalog-description: A study of principles and lab methods used in evaluation and diagnosis of the immune system and related diseases, augmented by the use of case studies. Development of critical thinking and problem solving techniques is emphasized. Restriction: must be enrolled in BSMLS Medical Laboratory Sciences.

course.title: Clinical Urinalysis
course.catalog-description: A study of kidney functions and the physiochemical and microscopic urine tests. Case studies, demonstrations and laboratory practice will enhance the development of critical thinking and problem solving skills needed in clinical urinalysis laboratory. Restriction: must be enrolled in BSMLS Medical Laboratory Sciences.

course.title: Laboratory Operations-Math
course.catalog-description: Introduction of all mathematics and quality control/assurance necessary for a competent laboratory scientist to succeed in the profession of medical laboratory scientist. Restriction: must be enrolled in MLS Certificate program.

course.title: Patient Care
course.catalog-description: This course acquaints the student with nursing procedures and techniques emphasizing the role of the diagnostic imager as a member of the health care team. Restriction: enrolled in Radiologic Sciences Program.

course.title: Patient Care Lab
course.catalog-description: This course covers the laboratory activities associated with 330. Restriction: permission of instructor.

course.title: Med Lang Systems Rev
course.catalog-description: This self-study course reviews the major systems of the human body, using a programmed textbook/workbook. The workbook format is combined with simple, non-technical explanations of medical terms and descriptions of anatomy, physiology, and pathology. Restriction: enrolled in Radiologic Sciences Program.

course.title: Med Imaging Thry III
course.catalog-description: Independent study course used for students completing upper-level baccalaureate coursework for the purpose of expanding on material covered in those courses. Restriction: enrolled in Radiologic Sciences Program and permission of instructor.

course.title: Computed Tomo Physics Review
course.catalog-description: Comprehensive examinations and topic review will take place throughout the semester. The registry review examinations will encompass the listed topics for students to demonstratre a basic knowledge of computed tomography and physics. Restriction: enrolled in Radiologic Sciences Program.

section.text: Internet course please visit http://online.unm.edu,Rescheduled from CRN 20252 RADS 412 001.

course.title: Computed Tomography Clin III
course.catalog-description: Course is a continuation of RADS 420 and RADS 421. Course provides additional clinical instruction in computed tomography including the system operation and components, image formation and reconstruction, characteristics of image quality, and artifact recognition/reduction. Prerequisites: 420 and 421. Restriction: enrolled in RADS degree program.

section.text: Online course, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu,Rescheduled from CRN 20237 RADS 422.001.

course.title: Current Issues
course.catalog-description: In depth discussions focusing on current issues facing the dental hygiene discipline. Restriction: DH majors only.

course.title: DH Research Methods
course.catalog-description: Developing of research in regard to special areas in dental hygiene with emphasis on writing reports. Restriction: DH majors only.

course.title: Extramural Exper
course.catalog-description: Provides the student with the opportunity to achieve educational and clinical skills and in depth knowledge in various dental care delivery systems. Restriction: DH majors only.

course.title: Current Issues
course.catalog-description: Restriction: DH majors only.

section.text: Online corse, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu

course.title: DH Internship
course.catalog-description: Restriction: DH majors only.

section.text: Online course, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Problems
course.catalog-description: Topical research and new procedures that cannot be accommodated in the regular dental hygiene curriculum. Restriction: DH majors only.

section.text: Online course, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Nonthesis
course.catalog-description: Restriction: DH majors only.

course.title: DH Thesis
course.catalog-description: Continuation of research, culminating in Master s Degree Thesis. The student is responsible for following procedures of the Office of Graduate Studies. Restriction: DH majors only.

section.text: Online course, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Accounting Cycle
course.catalog-description: An examination of accounting cycle topics in a corporation utilizing a web-based artificially intelligent assessment system. Topics include journal entries, transactions effects on accounts, adjusting entries, statement preparation, closing entries, and coverage of merchandising firms. Offered on a CR/NC basis only.

course.title: Ethical Pol & Social Envir
course.catalog-description: The influence of environmental change on the structure and operation of the organization. Social, political, economic, ethical and technological systems are examined as they relate to each other and to the management of small- and large-scale organizations. Prerequisite: ENGL 120.

course.title: Legal Issues for Managers
course.catalog-description: A general overview of the legal system and common legal principles. Emphasis on legal topics relevant to business such as contracts and torts. Explores sources of liability and presents strategies to minimize legal risk. Prerequisite: ENGL 120.

course.title: New Venture Strategies
course.catalog-description: Examines strategies, both personal and commercial, for effectively embarking on new ventures. Focuses on phase of entrepreneurship occurring between generation of the initial new venture idea, up to and including the first commercial sale. Prerequisite: ECON 106 and ENGL 120.

course.title: International Management
course.catalog-description: Provides an understanding of international operations and of international institutions in the private, not-for-profit and public sectors and of their managerial and environmental problems. Analyzes the structure, functions and decision-making of international organizations. Prerequisite: ECON 106.

course.title: Strategic Management
course.catalog-description: Emphasizes the functions of top management. Case studies offer the student an opportunity to develop a habit of administrative thinking as company-wide objectives and policies are formulated and consistent plans and programs are carried into action. Enrollment normally limited to students in final semester of B.B.A. Program. Prerequisite: 300 and 303 and 306 and 308 and 310 and 322 and 326 and 328.

course.title: Operations Design and Decision
course.catalog-description: A managerial level examination of operations strategy with emphasis on application of quantitative models as guides to managerial decision making. Includes project management, product and service design, Just-In-Time (lean systems), mass customization, and quality management. Prerequisite: 501.

course.title: Law for Accountants
course.catalog-description: An intensive examination of legal concepts underlying accounting theory and practice, selected topic in contracts, uniform commercial code, debtor-creditor relationships, business associations, government regulation of business property and professional and legal responsibility of accountants. Prerequisite: 540.

course.title: Governmental Accounting
course.catalog-description: Accounting and reporting for governmental entities. Introduces the basic principles of governmental accounting, including fund accounting, budgetary process, budget accounting of revenues, appropriations, disbursements, and assessments. Prerequisite: 340 or 540.

course.title: Operations Management
course.catalog-description: Survey of use of decision-making methods and models in the management and control of manufacturing, distribution, and service operating systems. Utilizes readings, problem solving, and projects to understand and apply concepts.

section.text: Online course, for information visit: http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Evidence-Based Practice
course.catalog-description: This course focuses on the principles of evidence-based nursing practice. Includes identification of clinical practice problems, evaluation of available evidence, and integration of evidence with clinical expertise and patient preferences in application to practice. Corequisite: 201 and 220L. Restriction: admission to B.S.N. program.

course.title: Community Assessment
course.catalog-description: Addresses community as client; determinants and indicators of community health. Student groups partner with communities to assess the health of a defined population and share planning for an evidence-based intervention for an identified problem. Pre- or corequisite: 340.

course.title: Ev Based Appl Hlth Assess Skls
course.catalog-description: Validation of core physical assessment skills is followed by development of holistic assessment strategies for clients across the lifespan. Application of evidence base and nursing judgment in selecting assessment strategies, diagnosis, and intervention planning. Pre- or corequisite: 340. Restriction: permission of advisor.

course.title: Family & Comm Hlth Pract
course.catalog-description: Focus on nursing roles working with families and communities as clients. Clinical experiences in case management and other community health roles will focus on understanding overall population health through contact with individuals and families. Prerequisite: 431L.

course.title: Application Health Ill Concept
course.catalog-description: Allows R.N. to B.S.N. students opportunity to explore in depth select concepts associated with an individual¿s physical health and illness. Concept categories include regulation and homeostasis, oxygen and hemostasis, protection, maladaptive behavior, emotions, and cognition. Pre- or corequisite: 340

course.title: Theoretical Found Adv Nurs
course.catalog-description: Examines selected theories in nursing and health. Approaches to the analysis, critique and utilization of theories in nursing practice and scholarship are emphasized. Students develop and apply a theory and analysis to an area of interest. Restriction: Admission to MSN program.

section.text: Online course visit http://online.unm.edu/schedule,Rescheduled from CRN 23993 NURS 501.061.

course.title: Research in Nursing
course.catalog-description: Examines methods used to research nursing problems and measure outcomes of therapeutic interventions. Emphasis on problem generation, framing problem theoretically, research designs and data measurement and analysis. Restriction: Admission to MSN program.

course.title: EBP in Nursing and Health Care
course.catalog-description: Systematic examination and application of health-related research in relation to advanced nursing practice, including: clinical practie, nursing education, nursing and health care administration, community an dpublic health, or health policy. Prerequisite: 503. Restriction: Admission to MSN program.

course.title: Hlth Care Poly Sys Adv Roles
course.catalog-description: Provides opportunity for in-depth discussion of concepts related to advanced practice. Focus in on issues affecting scope of practice, health policy, economics of health care, ethical decision making and advanced nursing roles and collaborative practice. Restriction: Admission to MSN program.

course.title: Faculty Roles & Prof Issues
course.catalog-description: Roles and competencies of nurse educators are examined within the context of various educational settings and philosophicla perspectives. Current political, social, cultrla, ethical, and pedagogical issues affecting the nurse educator are explored. Prerequisite: 501 and 503.

course.title: Pathophysiology Adv Pract Nurs
course.catalog-description: Application of analytical reasoning and problem solving based on pathophysiology and clinical presentations of a broad variety of diseases of children and adults across the life span.

course.title: Adult Health I
course.catalog-description: This course focuses on management of common primary health care problems of the young, middle, and older adult. Prerequisite: 526 and 540 and 543. Restriction: admitted to graduate program in nursing.

course.title: Differential Diag for Adv Prac
course.catalog-description: Builds on content covered in advanced courses of physical assessment, pharmacology and pathophysiology. Concepts of developing differential diagnosis related to health problems in acutely, chronically, and critically ill adults (all ages) based on case studies. Prerequisite: 566. Restriction: admitted to graduate program in nursing.

course.title: T: Nursing
course.catalog-description: Specialized courses about a particular topic in nursing. A variety of topic courses are offered according to demand. Different sections indicate different topic content. Restriction: admitted to graduate program in nursing.

course.title: Phil of Science in Nursing
course.catalog-description: Philosophy of Science analyzes ontonlogical and epistemological questions about knowledge, natural science, human science, nursing science and contexts of care. Learning strategies incorporate rigorous critical reflection and dialogue, analysis and synthesis of ideas, and the creative expression of thought. Restriction: admitted to doctoral program in nursing.

course.title: Rural & Cultural Health
course.catalog-description: Rural and cultural health analyzes unique characteristics, current issues, cultural competence and future trends for professional nursing in rural environments. Learning strategies incorporate critical reflection, dialogue, analysis and synthesis of ideas, problem-solving, rural experiences and the creative expression of thought. Restriction: admitted to doctoral program in nursing.

course.title: Evidence Policy & Politics
course.catalog-description: This course focuses on the use of evidence to influence institutional, local, state, federal and global health policies. Advocacy for influencing health policy is emphasized. Restriction: admission to doctoral program in Nursing.

section.text: Online course visit: http://online.unm.edu/schedule,Rescheduled from CRN 20254 NURS 640.060.

course.title: Appl Epidemiology Adv NSG Prac
course.catalog-description: Using group discussion, literature reviews, and primary and secondary data services, students will gain knowledge regarding the historical dimensions leading to health disparities, social injustice, and concepts of marginalization, poverty, race, class, and gender. Restriction: admission to doctoral program in Nursing.

course.title: Appl Clin Resrch Adv Nsg Pract
course.catalog-description: This course will focus on the systematic examination and application of health-related research in relation to advanced nursing practice, including clinical practice, nursing and health care administration, community and public health, or health policy. Restriction: admission to doctoral program in Nursing.

section.text: Online course visit: http://online.unm.edu/schedule,Rescheduled from CRN 23197 NURS 703.060.

course.title: Prin of Adv Nursing Management
course.catalog-description: This course introduces the importance of management skills, identifies essential management skills, and presents a learning model for developing management skills. Essential management skills are organized into three categories: personal, interpersonal, and group. Restriction: admission to doctoral program in Nursing.

section.text: Online course visit: http://online.unm.edu/schedule,Rescheduled from CRN 23473 NURS 725.060.

course.title: Hlth Innovations & Informatics
course.catalog-description: This course focuses on nursing informatics. Topics include: (1) introduction to the nursing informatics; (2) health care informatics applications; (3) evidence-based decision support; (4) information systems design; and (5) new opportunities and emerging trends. Restriction: admission to doctoral program in Nursing.

section.text: Online course visit: http://itv.unm.edu/schedule,Rescheduled from CRN 23198 NURS 727.060.

course.title: D.N.P. Capstone Project
course.catalog-description: In this course the student builds on the foundation of core and specialty content in the D.N.P. program to develop a rigorous project which reflects the achievement of D.N.P. program outcomes. Restriction: admission to doctoral program in Nursing.

course.title: Indig Self-Determination Educ
course.catalog-description: Examines the role of Indigenous people and communities in self-determining their education by redefining educational approaches and curriculum for Indigenous students. Special emphasis on resistance to assimilation practices and policies.

course.title: Experiential Learning Sem
course.catalog-description: Experiential learning involves collaborative, reflective investigation of real-world issues from a variety of personal, social and disciplinary perspectives. Extensive off-campus participation may be required. UNIV 175 may be linked with a corequisite course.

section.text: Online course visit http://online.unm.edu/schedule,60+ hrs required experiential learning project within US

course.title: T: Leadership Development
course.catalog-description: Prepares students to work in leadership positions on and off campus. Course may address Student Development Theory, Supplemental Instruction, Intentionally Structured Groups, critical thinking, learning styles, success skills, diversity, effective communication and group dynamics.

section.text: Online course visit http://online.unm.edu/schedule,Study Abroad students ONLY; 60+ hrs required,experiential learning project outside US

course.catalog-description: Deals with multiple causes of stress and its resolutions. Emphasizes chief stressors of adults, self-responsibility for change, holistic approach, emotional/mental methods of stress reduction.

course.catalog-description: Basic management of public funds, preparation and processing of budgets, revenue projection and expenditure controls. Issues of public policy and establishment of priorities through budgeting. (Required). Restriction: permission of academic advisor.

course.title: Professional Paper
course.catalog-description: Must be taken by all students who are not pursuing the thesis option. In general, papers will be more extensive than term papers, perhaps including case studies, reports of research results, theoretical essays or similar contributions of substantive and professional quality. Students must enroll for 3 hours the first semester, and then for 1 hour consecutively thereafter (including summer sessions), until their professional paper is approved. Only the first 3 credit hours will count toward the M.P.A. Restriction: permission of academic advisor.

course.catalog-description: A conceptual and practical introduction to health policy analysis and program evaluation. Although health policy and programmatic issues in the United States will be featured in the course, it will also examine international and comparative-method program evaluation cases and applications. Restriction: permission of academic advisor.

course.title: Topics in Philosophy
course.catalog-description: An investigation of some important philosophic debates. May be repeated six times for credit.

course.title: Social Justice in Education
course.catalog-description: Exploration of complex social justice issues and pedagogical responses. Focuses on knowledge and skills teachers need to integrate principles of social justice fully into classroom curriculum and instruction.

course.title: Elements of Calculus I
course.catalog-description: Limits of functions and continuity, intuitive concepts and basic properties; derivative as rate of change, basic differentiation techniques; application of differential calculus to graphing and minima-maxima problems; exponential and logarithmic functions with applications. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area II: Mathematics (NMCCN 1613). Prerequisites: ACT=>26 or SAT=>600 or MATH 121 or MATH 150 or Compass College Algebra >54. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Dynamics
course.catalog-description: Principles of dynamics. Kinematics and kinetics of particles, systems of particles and rigid bodies. Prerequisite: CE 202 and MATH 264.

Prerequisite: MATH 264 and PHYC 161. Pre- or corequisite: ECE 203L and MATH **316 . Restriction: ME major.

course.title: Introductory Microeconomics
course.catalog-description: Exploration of individual consumer behavior, production decisions by the firm and supply and demand relationships in the marketplace. Examination of the international dimension of production and consumption choices. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area IV: Social/Behavioral Sciences (NMCCN 2123). (Prerequisite for most upper division courses.)

course.title: Topics in Pop Cultr
course.catalog-description: Content varies by semester. Topics include: popular music, popular culture of the 1960s; sex and gender in popular culture; chicano/a vernacular culture; black popular culture; popular environmentalism.

course.title: T: Race Class Ethnicity
course.catalog-description: Offers specialized topics on an alternating basis dealing with race, class and ethnicity in the formation of American life and society. Subject areas include immigration, class formation, conquest, colonization, public policy and civil rights.

course.title: T: Chicano Hisp Mex Studies
course.catalog-description: Special topics in Chicano Hispano Mexicano Studies are interdisciplinary in nature and draw from the Humanities, Social Sciences, and the Arts. May be repeated as subject matter varies.

course.title: US History to 1877
course.catalog-description: Survey of the economic, political, intellectual and social development of the United States, including the place of the U.S. in world affairs from 1607 to 1877. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area V: Humanities and Fine Arts (NMCCN 1113). {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Elementary Spanish I
course.catalog-description: Beginning Spanish for students with no previous exposure to Spanish. Development of all four language skills, with emphasis on listening and speaking.

course.title: General Psychology
course.catalog-description: Overview of the major content areas in psychology. Topics to be covered include learning, cognition, perception, motivation, biological systems, social and abnormal psychology, development, personality and approaches to psychotherapy. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area IV: Social/Behavioral Sciences. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Statistical Principles
course.catalog-description: Presentation of the basic principles of the description and interpretation of data. Provides an acquaintance with statistical principles appropriate to a liberal arts education, as well as a basis for further work in data analysis. Students planning graduate study in any field are advised to take 300 and 302 as well. Prerequisite: 105.

course.title: Cognitive Psychology
course.catalog-description: Study of the cognitive processes involved in the encoding, storage, retrieval and use of knowledge including attention, memory, comprehension, categorization, reasoning, problem solving and language. Prerequisite: 105. {Fall, Spring}

section.text: Hybrid Course. 1.5 hrs taken online. http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Psychology Research Techniques
course.catalog-description: Application of the concepts covered in 200. Includes discussion of basic principles of research design and scientific methodology as applied to psychology. Prerequisite: 200.

course.title: Public Speaking
course.catalog-description: A performance course that deals with the analysis, preparation and presentation of speeches. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area I: Communications (NMCCN 1113).

course.title: Intermediate Algebra Part I
course.catalog-description: This course includes equations and inequalities, applications and problem solving with linear equations, linear functions and the graph of a line, percent, perimeters, areas of simple geometric shapes. Prerequisite: 100 or ISM 100 or (MATH 021 and MATH 022) or ACT Math => 19 or SAT Math => 450 or COMPASS Pre-Algebra => 57 or COMPASS Algebra =>34. Corequisite: 102.

course.title: Intermediate Algebra Part II
course.catalog-description: This course includes quadratic equations, properties of exponents and scientific notation, simplifying polynomial expressions, factoring and introduction to functions. Prerequisite: 101.

course.title: Intermediate Algebra Part III
course.catalog-description: This course includes radical expressions and equations, rational expressions and equations, the exponential and logarithm functions. Pre- or corequisite: 102.

course.title: College Algebra
course.catalog-description: Preparation for MATH 150 and 180. The study of equations, functions and graphs, especially linear and quadratic functions. Introduction to polynomial, rational, exponential and logarithmic functions. Applications involving simple geometric objects. Emphasizes algebraic problem solving skills. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area II: Mathematics (NMCCN 1113). Prerequisite: ACT=>22 or SAT=>510 or (MATH 118 and MATH 119) or (MATH 101 and MATH 102 and MATH 103) or MATH 120 or Compass Algebra >54 or College Algebra >33. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Intro To Philosophy
course.catalog-description: Philosophical issues and methodology illustrated through selected problems concerning values, knowledge, reality; and in social, political and religious philosophy. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area V: Humanities and Fine Arts (NMCCN 1113).

section.text: Hybrid Course. 1.5 hrs taken online. http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Living World Religions
course.catalog-description: Introduction to major living world religions, such as Buddhism, Christianity, Hinduism, Islam and Judaism.

section.text: Hybrid Course. 1.5 hrs taken online. http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Study of Literature
course.catalog-description: An introduction to the study and appreciation of literature for non-English majors. Shows how understanding writers' techniques increases the enjoyment of their works; relates these techniques to literary conventions; teaches recognition, analysis, discussion of important themes.

course.title: Introduction to Sociology
course.catalog-description: Basic concepts, topics and theories of contemporary sociology. Meets New Mexico Lower Division General Education Common Core Curriculum Area IV: Social/Behavioral Sciences (NMCCN 1113). Prerequisite for more advanced courses in sociology. {Summer, Fall, Spring}

course.title: Causes of Crime & Delinquency
course.catalog-description: A survey of criminological theories exploring why some people are more likely to engage in crime than others and why crime rates vary over time and space and across social groups. Attendant policy issues will also be discussed. Prerequisite: 205 or 211 or 213. {Fall, Spring}

section.text: Rescheduled from CRN 23891 SOC 312 001.,Hybrid Course. 1.5 hrs taken online. http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Youth & Society
course.catalog-description: An assessment of the creation and dynamics of childhood and youth in human societies. Consideration of historical and cross-cultural material; and issues such as deviance and popular culture. Prerequisite: 101.

section.text: Hybrid Course. 1.5 hrs taken online. http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Special Topic in Sociology
course.catalog-description: May be repeated for credit as subject matter varies, no limits. {Offered upon demand}

section.text: Rescheduled from CRN 23892 SOC 398 001.,Hybrid Course. 1.5 hrs taken online. http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Soc of Police & Social Control
course.catalog-description: Study of the relationship between society and law enforcement agencies, including the societal context of policing and how law enforcement impacts society. Discussion of law enforcement practices, training and management; the interface of police and communities; historical and contemporary models of policing; and efforts at police reform. Prerequisite: 312. {Fall, Spring}

section.text: Reschedule from CRN 23898 SOC 412 001.,Hybrid Course. 1.5 hrs taken online. http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Youth & Adult Crime
course.catalog-description: Causes and consequences of offending at various stages in the life course, focusing on the ways in which adolescent and adult roles, responsibilities and opportunities shape aggregate and individual level patterns of involvement in juvenile delinquency and adult criminality. Prerequisite: 312.

section.text: Hybrid Course. 1.5 hrs taken online. http://online.unm.edu

course.title: Drugs Crime & Social Control
course.catalog-description: Study of the development of social policies concerning illicit substance use; its impact on social behavior; strategies for prevention and intervention with substance use; investigation, adjudication and supervision of drug offenders; and the relationship between criminal justice, education, public health and government policies. Prerequisite: 312.

section.text: Hybrid Course. 1.5 hrs taken online. http://online.unm.edu

course.title: T:Latin American Studies
course.catalog-description: Will vary from instructor to instructor, but will be an in-depth analysis of special topics related to Latin America. For course content, consult the Schedule of Classes. The course may be repeated without limit provided the topics vary.

course.title: Computing for Bus Students
course.catalog-description: Students will use personal computers in campus laboratories to learn use of a word processor, a spreadsheet and a database management program. The course will also cover access to the World Wide Web and other topics of current importance to business students. Course cannot apply to major or minor in Computer Science. Prerequisite: (MATH 101 and MATH 102 and MATH 103) or MATH 120 or MATH 121 or MATH 123 or MATH 150 or MATH 162 or MATH 163 or MATH 180 or MATH 181.

course.title: Hum Res Mgt: Pub Sec
course.catalog-description: Survey of human resources management principles and practices in public sector organizations. (Required.) Restriction: permission of academic advisor.
